FYI: pronouncing it 'de Brown' would be more accurate.
'Bruijn' is Dutch old-timey spelling of 'Bruin' (which is.. Actually also Dutch for Brown).

There's no equivalent for the 'ui' sound in English, but the 'ow' in 'brown' is the closest you can get.

It's logical that you would try to pronounce it like 'ruin' (looks quite a lot like it), but yeah..
There's only one syllable; not 2.

For funsies, you can check out online dictionary pronunciations of 'ui' (onion), or bruin (brown), or tuin (garden).
(It's a specifically Dutch thing, I think. Not sure I know of any other languages that use this)

Easy way to hacker-proof an old 8 bit  garage door opener:  Use a remote lamp switch to power the opener.  A local home supply store had two types, one with a 80 ft and another with a 140 ft range. The current ratings were large enough for a 1/2 HP opener motor but normally the relay in the remote controller will not make or break the motor current; only carry the motor current. One remote for each can be used if more than one garage door.  Another way is a WiFi outlet controlled with a smartphone but this is more cumbersome to use.

So I watched this video a couple weeks ago and totally forgot about it. I just woke up today from a dream where a similar system was being abused (although physically, the victim would see you doing the attack so it made no sense to even try). Anyway, the solution in my dream was to randomize the codes, so that each time you pressed it could be the right code or the wrong code (selected from a pool). Now that I think about it, a better solution would be to have a set of randomly generated codes, make sure the correct code isn't the last one (or two), then send the discrete codes one by one. That way the user doesn't have to keep pressing the button like 50 times to open their garage and even if the jammer collects the right code it gets used up and fed a bogus code. To go even further, randomize how many codes get sent. That way the attacker can't figure out that the correct code will always be one of the first six (as an example) and have a 1/36 chance at opening the garage door (1/6 for the first code 1/6 for the second which isn't great for the attacker, but still a higher chance than we would like). It's randomizers all the way down. There's obviously still some minuscule chance that the jammer can collect two correct codes if the jammer scans at just the right intervals, for example, but I think it's unlikely enough to be secure for a residential garage home.

I used to write firmware for security receivers, and a lot of inexpensive garage door openers are simple 8- bit pulse position format, but as you guys found out the timing is everything.  The codes I used were PPM and PWM and 24 to 32 bits in length and sometimes included hamming and grey encoding, but the reception windows were very tight ( to about 50uS) and in some formats they used a sync pulse to specify the widths of the pulse windows so the timing would be different in different conditions.

The video is actually incorrect. The toy can't open ANY garage, only old and obsolete garage door openers that are still 8 or 12 bit. While breaking into a rolling code garage is certainly possible, this toy doesn't do it, and it becomes much harder as you have to interfere with the original code while capturing both that code and the next generated code.

Keep in mind that for that to happen, you would have to be relatively close to the house, and in gated community like his or with a gate, probably wouldn't be that easy to pull off without looking pretty suspicious loitering in the neighborhood.

Also, most upscale or newer neighborhoods would already have rolling code openers or even smart openers where your phone lets you know your garage has been opened. So, this method is full of risks and holes.

A very secure way to prevent any of these from working would be to have the door opener send the current time, followed by the signature of the current time. The garage door compares the received time to make sure it is within a window of its own time, say within 10 seconds to account for drift, signs the received time with the same signing key, and compares the 2. If they are the same signature, the door opens.

the wild bit is that the de Bruijn sequence is not the shortest possible

the shortest possible arrangenents are called superpermutations, and while the length of the 8-bit superperm isn't known, 4-chan has found the formula which can predict this length very accurately, which then allows computers to directly attack perms at that length and we should soon know the 8-bit superperm, which is somewhere around half the length of the de Bruijn sequence. It's called the Haruhi problem and the solution is the Haruhi theorem.

In fact, the superperm is so efficient that it becomes possible to crack the rolling code opener with the superperm as well.

I came up with my own protocol for an automotive remote control. Uses a Fob ID, and a random number with a lot of "swirling" (shifts, flips, XORs) to create a 128-bit burst. It's very weak "encryption" (obscurity only - "key" goes with the "lock"), but spectrally it's white (important, to harden against analysis). More importantly, this is only for the wake-up "hello" to the RX radio transceiver - and it has a few extra features: rate limiting (one attempt every 3 seconds), and packet size (128-bits).

After the RX radio wakes up it begins a secure bidirectional session with elliptic curve with pre-shared public keys (from setup), HMAC, time limits (RTC), and a counter.

It has a full wake up, Car-to-Fob, Fob-to-Car loop time of 1.5 seconds - slower than your off-the-shelf car alarm or factory remote, but it's not going to be replayed, spoofed, or MiM. Was a balance between security, functionality, speed, power consumption, and range - uses TI's CC1312R on both ends.

Encryption over the internet - 128 bits and short lived is considered meh. Garage door 12 bits with no time limit is considered secure and 8 bits ok and it doesn't even ensure the bits are part of one signal so it is in practice not even the bits advertised (though using a specific rate of bits can make it a bit more secure). Fixed code systems are very easy to hack if you can get your hands on that particular kind of opener.  Just build a binary counter one bit longer than the system, port the counter MSBs into the dip switch settings, and port the counter LSB to the "pushbutton".  Then give your counter a square wave and let it count.  I did it 37 years ago and in about fifteen minutes it opened all the garage doors in my neighborhood that were within transmit range of my living room.  Yes, the builder put the same brand of garage door opener in each house.

I always thought a system that had 2 way communication between the receiver and the clicker would work.

First you would sync the devices with a physical connection. You could also do this to reset the lookup table which I'm about to mention.
The receiver would create a lookup table of key value pairs all unique which would be stored on both the receiver and the clicker.
Then when you click open, the clicker sends a message that says, please open.
The receiver, upon receiving that message sends a key from its lookup table.
The clicker upon receiving that key would send back the correct value.
Each key value pair would only be used once and the device would create millions of them so you would be unlikely to run out.

You don't need a transmitter or toy to open most garage doors. Here is a little known fact that has come in handy many times during power outages before I installed a battery back-up. In most garages, the latch at the inside top of the door that connects and disconnects with the center guide rail is easily accessible using a wire coat hanger. Just slipping a wire coat hanger between the door frame and door with the hook part to catch and release the latch with a downward yank will open most garage doors. Thieves know this, so should you!

In the room next to the garage I built a smallish Tesla coil, generating some nice 100mm arcs. Whenever I activated the Tesla coil, all three doors would randomly go up and down. The field was modulating the high impedance input of the manual override button, bypassing the receiver and the code sequence.

The problem with such solutions is that nothing stands in the way of any would-be thief purchasing such a system themselves. This way you have a safe environment to test out the physical characteristics of the system (frequency, baud, pulse width etc.) and, once they have it finely tuned - they can just leave a recorder in the vicinity to try and intercept a legit signal. Further, I wouldn't be suprised if data on many of these was already available on the Internet, or being provided by someone who does this sort of thing for a living (while technically not breaking any laws, no less). Though to be honest, I'd expect such from a determined thief - it's much easier to go after the low-hanging fruit (put such a device together and see which doors respond - then rob those at a later date).

Wait, doesn't the garage door need to send backs a message to the controller to tell it that it has received the code so they are both synchronized? If you jam the signal on the first code, the controller will just try to send the first code again and you won't have a future code, because the garage door wouldn't respond with a synchronizing signal that would tell the controller to move on to the next code in the sequence. If that wasn't the case and the controller just kept sending codes further and further away along the sequence without them reaching the garage door (say if you were very far away and kept fidgeting with it), so when you finally used it on the garage door it either wouldn't open or would simply keep going along its own counter until it synchronized with your controller, which means that it would do that for any code it ever received with the appropriate length. I don't think that hacking method would actually work, unless you also intend to send a fake synchronizing signal back to the controller and jammed the synchronizing signal coming from the garage door itself, which sounds like something that would have a very low success rate.

The only usable numbers are those in the future, in fact up to 64 codes ahead. Then the instant a valid code is received all past codes are forgotten in the receiver and are ignored for 2 to power 32 presses. So all previously recorded data strings are now worthless. Secondly the part where they placed junk data in the beginning of the valid data was fake. All chips need a sync period to determine where the data word starts from. The de bruijn sequence will not work on serial data transmission as used in remote controls. Believe me this video is all garbage. And anyone who believes this and orders one of these "Openers" is only going to be handing over money to scammers who stand to make money out of the poor public who don't know any better. haha. Nice video though. I commend the effort they went to in making this video.

Re: rolling codes - not entirely correct.

Yes, you could technically see a code, grab it, and emit a jamming signal. Then do it again, like you mentioned, to have a "future" code.

However...the garage door openers have a window of (usually 10 or more) "future" codes that it will accept as valid in addition to the current code. Otherwise, if there were interference between the remote and the door, or the remote was pressed far away from the door, the two would be out of sequence, and you would have to reprogram the remote to the opener before it would work again. People would be annoyed and think it was broken.

Let's say both the opener and the remote are on code N. You press the remote while at the grocery store. Now the opener is still on N, but the remote is on N+1. On the way home, your toddler presses the remote again. Now the remote is on N+2, but the opener is still on N.

You get home, press the remote, but you're too far away, so it isn't received by the opener. The remote is on N+3, but the opener is still on N. So you pull up closer to the garage and press the remote again. The remote transmits N+3, the opener says, "yup, that's valid" and opens the door.

But here's the important thing: The opener now says, "OK, I've missed a few presses, but I received N+3 as valid, so now THAT is the valid code. The old N, N+1 and N+2 will not be seen as valid." Both the remote and the opener switch to N+4.

So in your situation, your future code would be "killed" as soon as the opener DID receive a valid code from the remote, which would be pretty much immediately, because the owner would want to get into his garage.

Incidentally, this is also exactly how hotel locks work. The front desk encodes "room 302, rolling code 5" onto your card's magstripe. You insert the card into the door lock of room 302. The door lock says, "well, I'm still on code 4, but now I see a valid code 5, so I will disable code 4 and switch to code 5." Now all code 5 cards will open the door.

As soon as another card is encoded for the room, it will receive code 6, which when used in the lock, will disable code 5 and switch the lock to code 6.

In case the hack method at the end was not clear:
You hide a small electronic device that listen and record codes and also jam the garage opener frequency.
When owner press remote with code #1, you record it.
Since the door didn't open, the user press the remote again.
You record that new code and quickly replay the first code to the garage opener.
It should accept that code. Later, when owner leave, you may replay the second code.
This technic would work if the code never expire.
With more secure systems, both garage door and remote have a binary counter acting as clock.
The encryption key rely on the value of this clock to match with some margin to accept slightly different time, since those clocks will drift.

I'm working on computer & network security, I can tell 2 to the power of 12 (4096 possibilities) is really really low security. Even if you're using random seeds algorithms. Maybe too much for an IM-ME, but not for a phone or
For comparison, MD5 is a HASH-based algorithm that's obsolete, even tho it's 2 to the power of 128. (340 282 366 920 938 463 463 374 607 431 768 211 456 possibilities!!!!)

This means that you can grab ANY laptop, buy some high-spectrum frequency generator and open in less than a second 99% of all garages, cars, lock systems... (Other 1% have 2 steps systems, banks for example)

The most optimal system I can think of is this:
P2P RSA 2048 bits tunnel, on which it will travel one changing SHA-256 bits key based on a random seed.

It's the same system of which a browser connects securely to an HTTPS server and sends your password through except because of the seed.
It first stablishes the encrypted tunnel (so the key can't be seen while traveling, and so can't clone it) and the original key is never known even if an attacker grabs the hashed key. Because you can't get the original key by only knowing the hash.

This would also enable the owner to use a homemade key (for example your WIFI password and sync the garage with your phone).

So yeah, it could be A LOT more secure by only adding a few bucks.

The more we rely on online services, the more vulnerable we become. Bigger companies are a bigger target than an individual. Allowing a company to keep track of your accounts plus passwords, you make it easier for your account to get hack. We hear it all the time of companies being hacked and users data being leaked, passwords data being exposed. When we rely on these companies, we put our trust in them that they will protect our data. Lastpass has not been around as long as some of these other companies have, and yet these other companies have been hacked and our data has been leaked. Two-hundred accounts? Pfft. I've managed to accumulate about a thousand total accounts of various sorts, each with a unique and complex password that uses the maximum allowed complexity for each account. The exception being my fully encrypted Linux computer. I'm not going to type 512 characters just to start booting my computer. However, about one-fifth that I am willing to do. Why? Why not? If someone breaks into my home and steals my computer, I want to make sure my data is safe. If an account gets compromised, I don't want it to mean any other account gets compromised. The only password manager you will ever need is KeePass. It's free, works on multiple platforms (including Android), and comes with a password generator that you can use to create unique complex passwords quickly and easily. All you have to remember is one complex password for the KeePass database. Of course, something nobody likes to talk about is general computer security. It's amazingly easy for an attacker to get a keylogger or backdoor on your computer. Your computer should always be kept updated, which means ALL software on the computer. You should have an adequate firewall (or two). A firewall on the computer and another between your computer and the internet, such as on your router. The firewall(s) should be properly configured. You should have some form of antivirus/antimalware system setup. Your browser should have respectable addons to force HTTPS, block ads by default, and to control cookies/history. uBlock origin, Privacy Badger, and HTTPS everywhere are good for this. Don't think you could be hacked? Hacks happen, and very often. A good hacker will compromise your computer/account without you even knowing until the damage is done. There are black markets on the dark webs selling stolen credit cards and other personal information. Don't get caught up in this, take precautions. Nobody is perfect and no system is perfect, but hackers tend to go for easy targets. The harder you are as a target, the less likely you will get screwed. Keep in mind though that any website you input anything of value (such as credit card information) could get compromised and your valuable data could still be stolen and sold. Keep an eye on your financial accounts and credit score. There is a free service that can keep you informed of credit changes. Learn everything you need to do. For example, with my bank, if I notice suspicious activity on my bank account, if I report it within 48 hours, I have no liability. The longer it takes me to notice it and report it, the more liable I become. It also helps to have the phone numbers you need to call to cancel cards inside of a KeePass database that you can access on your phone and computer. That way, if you lose your wallet or it gets stolen, you can quickly cancel the cards. Another note as well, split up your password databases. It's risky to open a password database containing your financial information on a cell phone while trying to log into some app. Keep your financial information on secured desktop computers. You could have one database for website logins in general, one for financial credentials, one for apps/cell phone related credentials, and so forth. Backup every database often and keep copies on multiple devices, even if you never plan to open them on said devices. The point is that in case one device gets stolen or destroyed in some manner, you still have backups. You can even throw a copy on Google Drive and other "private" online file storage services. The password database is encrypted and the more backups you have, the better.

What about time-based dynamic codes? I know, keeping the devices in sync is challenging, but it's possible to transmit encrypted time with the precision of milliseconds on each successful operation so the clocks would sync up. If you get and leave home every day, that's not a huge deal since the offset in that period is so miniscule, the codes would still work, but if you leave for months, you might get locked-out. For most people, it would work like a charm.

Also, you could still use the sequence-based rolling codes but with a three-wave handshake — the devices would exchange codes three times in a row, in a way that the next sequence would depend on the previous and a seed, so if it got jammed on the first transmission, the attacker hasn't got the next signal in the sequence because the seed is kept secret, and if it got jammed on the next step, the entire sequence would get thrown out on both devices. For enhanced security, you could use separate seeds for each step.

Most rolling code systems calculate and store as many as 200 codes in advance. If you push the button and the opener doesn't react, the codes become de-synced. The remote could be 9 or 10 codes ahead of the opener, but it can still be used because the opener has stored these codes in advance.

"Learning" openers aren't really secure either, since the secret encryption key is typically reused in other remotes by each manufacturer. Once you know that secret key, you can crack any opener by capturing a code using a rogue receiver and running it through the KeeLoq algorithm using that manufacturer's secret key. This vulnerability is especially dangerous because this is the system that auto manufacturers use for keyless entry systems. All of the car manufacturers are known to use the same secret key for every single vehicle and key fob they make, with the only difference being the serial numbers of both the key and the car. The same thing applies to "smart keys" with engine immobilizers.

For example, if you figure out the secret key that Ford uses for all of its keyless entry systems, you can break into most Ford vehicles once you capture the key fob's serial number and button mapping information, both of which are sent in plaintext for some reason. Not that it matters whether the serial number is encrypted or not, since you will have discovered the key anyway. It's not just Ford that does this, either. All auto makers do it this way because if they changed the crypt key, you wouldn't be able to program a replacement or spare remote.

I think that any honest advisor would tell you that you need not a password manager but a personally made up algorithm to help you remember your passwords or generate new ones. It can (and should) even be complex, after all you only need to learn to master it once and for all. For a user, it is as easy and convenient as having a single password. For a hacker, it is even harder to hack than your password manager. If you use a password manager you might as well worry yourself sick about protecting your computer against malicious software because having it hacked would be seriously catastrophic. No need to mention the risk if synced across all your devices. All you need to do is lose one, or use it on an unencrypted network. If you have an algorithm in your head, with one single parameter (easliy remembered, unguessable, that you could even implicitly write down somewhere innocent-looking) for each of them, it is absolutely unbreakable unless intercepted when the password is entered (and that only risk is just as high with a password manager). On top of that, if you are burgled with a laptop containing 320 passwords you haven't a clue of, there it all goes. Even if the passwords aren't discovered, you can no longer use them yourself. So you need to know your passwords anyway, so password managers, regardless of how unsafe I claim them to be, are pointless. Don't be over-reliant, be smart and wary.

An observation on pronouncing 'De Bruijn'; it's a Dutch name (meaning roughly 'the brown') and also found in Afrikaans where the 'ij' has morphed into 'y' so becoming 'de Bruyn' (in Afrikaans names beginning with the word de/le/le/etc. are typically not uppercased). The Afrikaans name is pronounced as 'de brain' and I'm pretty sure the Dutch one will be very similar.

A solution to this risk of stealing a future code would be for the manufacturers to implement a handshake system to verify the receiver got the code. If it didn’t get the code, the remote should not advance to the next one. Essentially, don’t generate the next code unless the receiver actually got the current one and sent an acknowledgment back to the remote. This in theory would allow a future code to never be captured by a hacker. Seems like a common sense solution to me.

"They won't be able to predict what the next number is, even if they knew the algorithm." ← This is generally NOT true! This is true only in the case of cryptographically secure pseudo random number generators. Mersenne twister, which Derek selected here in the demo, is NOT SECURE to use. Specifically, after listening to 624 openings of a garage door that uses Mersenne twister, you can predict the next code, so assuming that the garage door is opened twice a day, after eavesdropping for not even a year, you can break in.

When I first bought my place, I would sometimes come home to an open garage door even though I had closed it that morning. Realizing the garage door opener was 25 years old, I could have purchased a new one, but I wanted to do it myself. I ended up taking apart the garage door opener and disabling the circuit that listens to RF. After I verified that the RF remote no longer worked, I bought a Photon (www.store.particle.io) and wired it to an external relay which I attached to the external terminals on the opener. I then wrote a tiny bit of C code that runs on the Photon that waits for a signal before triggering the relay. After doing this, I wrote a very simple Android app that sends the signal. The result is that my ancient 25-year-old garage door opener now only responds to my Android app :-)

De Bruijn sequences! so dear to my heart because I discovered them independently about twenty years ago (although I found out only this year that I was far from being the first to do so). Perhaps not surprisingly, it was a problem very similar to garage-opening codes that led me to the discovery. Old answering machines used to use a 2-digit code to access messages. (Some perhaps still do.) It occurred to me that at least some such machines might use a 2-digit rolling buffer, which led me to wonder whether there might be a string of digits that contained every 2-digit number exactly once. With a little trial and error, I soon discovered my first 101-digit example. I then found more systematic ways to produce such strings in different bases with substrings of different length. Here's a particularly carefully ordered string containing all the 2-digit sequences from 00 to 99:

00110221203323130443424140554535251506656463626160776757473727170887868584838281809989796959493929190.

And here it is again, arranged in a triangle so that the base increases by one with each new line, from bases one to ten:

00
110
22120
3323130
443424140
55453525150
6656463626160
776757473727170
88786858483828180
9989796959493929190
...

The pattern should be fairly obvious, and could be continued indefinitely.

Of course, for 2-figure codes (strictly speaking, "digit" applies only to numbers in base ten), the saving, compared to stringing together all codes in full, is rather low, at just under half the figures. For 3-figure codes, it is almost two-thirds; for 4-figure codes, it is almost three-quarters (three-fourths); and so on. The beauty of arranging the numbers in order of increasing base is that the string can be interrupted immediately after the nth zero (n > 1), having produced, up to that point, all 2-figure sequences in all bases up to (n ‒ 1). So, for example, the sequence 0011022120 (interrupted immediately after the 4th zero) contains, exactly once, all 2-figure sequences in bases 1 to 3.

The same basic principles can be applied just as easily to strings of letters: AABBACCBCA...

The next problem with the rolling code systems is that there are a lot of "weak" seeded random number algorithms around and in use.

With "weak", I mean that the internal state, and sometimes even the seed, can be recovered after observing a few random numbers, just by analyzing the algorithm and solving some simple equations.

After that, an attacker can predict ALL future (and sometimes past) codes produced by the device.

Examples for this are C's rand() and srand() functions, or Java's java.util.Random, which can be broken by a second semester CS-Student or anyone spending enough time with it (I've done it myself)

Algorithms like MersenneTwister are harder to break, but there exist public tools even for that.

What CAN be used for a reproducible, but random looking series of bits is to use a strong encryption algorithm like AES and use it to continuously re-encrypt it's result, or use a mode like Counter-mode to produce new values.

The bit at the end re having to get the baud etc right: true, but fixable by passively listening to one instance of the real thing, like you showed at the top w/ the garage door opener. Of course, parameters like frequency, length, etc also can be generated by a HOTP ("rolling" code), becoming part of the key rather than a fixed setup thing. (Same applies to "frequency hopping" — depends if the hop sequence is fixed vs generated.) The replay issue can be fixed using TOTP (where it's seed + current datetime, not seed + # times used), which is what Google Authenticator & other hardware 2 factor auth generally use.

I just thought of a nice way to avoid all this corporate system bull crap and still be a lot safer than this 8 bit and 12 bit nonsense.

1. Get a raspberry pi and a voltage controller to interface with the rollers that roll the doors.
2. Connect your raspberry pi to your home wifi
3. If your wifi range doesn't extend it near your garage door, extend it using a range extender
4. Write a basic Java program on raspberry pi that listens to a certain key phrase on a certain port number. When it gets the key on the port number, it will send the voltage signal to the roller system to open the doors
5. Write a one line piece of code for the phone to send the key to raspberry pi's IP and port number with the key as the message. Execute it using terminal emulator for android (not sure what the equivalent for iOS is).
6. Done

If an attacker wants to hack your garage door, he will have to first hack into your wifi, figure out you use a raspberry pi to unlock your garage, figure out the ip and port number and then figure out the message. In case you are too paranoid about the key being too basic, write some extra code to generate private and public keys using RSA. Amazing solution.

Edit:
Another better way to generate a key is to use hashing on both sides. On both sides, the hash is calculated every second and the hash function also updates every second - > md5hash(current hours, seconds, date, month, year + some custom message). Since this 128 bit hash code updates every second and it's almost impossible to duplicate or brute force it every second, it's I think the most secure way of going about this.

Correct me if I am wrong, but if someone uses the brute force approach to hack a garage door, then even if the transmitter-receiver pair uses a rolling code, the attacker would still eventually get the correct code by trying every combination.  I believe the reason why the 3rd garage door didn't open is that the length of a rolling code is much longer than that of a fixed code.  While the fixed code of the garage door in the video is only 8 or 12 bits long, a rolling code using the Keeloq protocol has 66 data bits, with 32 bits encrypted with the rolling code.  There are simply a lot more combinations of bits and therefore takes much longer to hack by brute force

So this concept of using a shift register and checking for a code match each time a digit is recieved also applies to the keypads on Ford vehicles. The guys who wrote a book called "The Car Hackers Handbook" discovered this and found you can use a de Bruijn sequence here as well to enter all possible codes by hand in maybe half an hour. But I already knew of Samy's opening garage doors this way, and it inspired me to make a Ford door unlocking robot. It can open a Ford car door on older vehicles before they implemented an "anti-scan" feature in usually only a few minutes. https://hackaday.io/project/27445-five-finger-code-finder

For rolling code, as computer get more and more powerfull, it start to become easy to actually crack the code. The algo is known, and if you can get atleast one keypress (more is better) then you can simply brute force it.

Basically you loop throught every seed possible, and compare the result with the code you grabbed. It is possible that there is some colisions (more than one seed produce the same code) hence why more than one code is good for confirmation. Once you get a match you can simply go open the door.

All you need now is send a code that is a few sequence after the last known. The receiver will accept many after the last one that worked, because each keypress increment the counter. Since the transmitter can be out of range, it's counter will increase, but not the receiver one obiviously, hence why it accept many (possibly over 1000!) code past the last known counter...

Fun thing: you can simply start by the last known code, and increment the counter until the door open. When the owner come back, the first keypress won't work, but the second will (or third if you also closed the door with the transmitter).

Fun fact. There is already a "Skeleton Signal" It's similar in concept to the de Bruijn sequence. You can play it for any device, it is 10 minutes long, and it will unlock anything that receives it that doesn't use end to end encryption/two way communication(something that sends data and expects a result based on the data and re-encrypted back to sender). A friend at college used it to hack into laundry mats, car garages, NFC badge readers, Car locks, some parking meters, even some swipe card readers are so sensitive that it also works on those. So what's the difference between a de Bruijn Sequence and a Superpermutation?

The Mersenne Twister is a really terrible example, it is not cryptographically secure and it's actually trivial to recover the internal state simply by looking at the random outputs for a while. Some simpler random number generators (common in microcontroller applications like this) are even worse. What you really need is a CSPRNG a.k.a. a stream cipher. Even the old (broken) RC4 is much more secure than a Mersenne Twister.

tl;dr Security is hard, if you ever need to design a system like this, then either use an established protocol, or contact someone who has actually studied cryptography instead of rolling your own solution which is almost guaranteed to be insecure.

Both my fiancée and myself worked for Liftmaster/Chamberlain's customer service department and we couldn't believe other companies still pushed fixed-code systems. There's also a lot of stagnation on the consumer side of things, i.e. people often keep their cheap (usually older Genie) openers for 30-40 years, there's even more stagnation for gate openers because they are much more expensive to replace. A motor breaking is more of an incentive to replace than any security flaw, however massive. The more aware people are of this issue the better. Of course modern Liftmaster/Chamberlain openers are now IOT devices which opens a whole additional security backdoor with its own set of issues, albeit still vastly more secure than any fixed-code system.

Hardy garage door.
Motion sensor light.
Rolling code garage door.
Mechanical only garage door.
Home security system
Do not keep valuable stuff in garage
Keep good homeowners insurance policy
Keep dog in garage
Warning sign of dog
motion sensor camera with alert
Neighbor cooperation

Incorrect about finding the seed from the pseudorandom sequence. The seed of Linear congruential generators can be inferred with something like a number of outputs proportional to the number of bits in the seed. So if your seed is a 32 bit number, it only takes something like 32 outputs to reveal the seed. I once did a demo over USENET where I implemented an algorithm from a thesis and de-crypted a message XORed with a pseudorandom sequence. Granted that capturing 32 garage door openings would be pretty ambitious, but I wouldn't be surprised if there were 8 and 16 bit seeds used in openers. The effort of that would be commensurate with dumpster diving or just breaking a window, though. So maybe it's enough for home use.

EDIT: The Thesis is from Joan Boyar, University of Chicago, published in JACM Jan. 1989. Inferring sequences produced by pseudo-random number generators.

Someone below is asking  that the rolling code can't work the way its told here. As if the receiver accepts only  the next code what will happen if the transmitter is out of range and someone presses the button of transmitter ? As now transmitter has moved ahead of receiver.               Well the video lacks a few things here.  Actually there is a synchronization counter C which gets increamented each time you press the key (of transmitter).  Same way the receiver also stores the most recent validated synchronization counter it has received (N).   Now when ever you press the key and send the pseudo-random number to the transmitter the transmitter also takes the synchronization counter C from transmitter (and to update itself will overwrite N with C).  Now receiver will also produce the Cth code (corresponding to C i mean) and match with the code send by transmitter. There is also rolling window of acceptance for rolling codes say 100 or 1000 or whatever (depending upon which system you using for your garrage or car keys).  Now also note that  C-N <= window  of acceptance.   Hope you are getting my point here. Means if you window of acceptance is say 1000 and you press your key 1000 times when you were out of the range then the garrage (or your car or whatever) will ignore the key even if you come back to range.   Also note that if press the key and hold it pressed it keeps emitting same bits, its only when you press it again (press, release the button and press again) that you are generating a new code.  The attack works because the tranmitter checks if the next number is what falls in the sequence and there is no concept of expire due to time here (like we have in one time passwords sent to phone).

Little thing you guys might find interesting.

The reason why the garage uses bit shifting (that's what it's called when it throws out the first bit and 'moves' it along taking the next bit [which is usually 0]) is because it is literally faster. CPU's are able to handle bit shifting faster than, as far as I'm aware, every other operation it carries out.
As bit shifting is the equivalent to preforming a multiplication factor of two, it's more efficient to bit shift say 7 times than to do a multiplication of 64 on the number 1. The reason why it's faster is because the arithmetic unit of the CPU needs to switch more bits than bit shifting does, which only switches a few bits - as bit's are in the format of: 1->2->4->8->16->32->64->e.c.t. but in reverse.
Take for example; 01000000, this is the equivalent to 64. Lets take the number 1; 00000001, and left bit shift it 8 times: 10000000 - this is 128. Note that all the cpu would have to do is flip the first bit and the last bit (bit 1 and bit 8), the arithmetic unit - again - would take more time to do this.

It is possible to do any multiplication - not just a multiple of 2 - with bit shifting, but it's very inneficient.
E.g:
multiplication of 35 of 2 (which = 70):
1. find the nearest power for 2^ to the multiplication number and store 2^ the number you found and store it. I.e. 6 -> 2^6 = 32
2. do the multiplication number, minus the above one and store it. I.e. 35-32=3
3. do the inital number multiplied by the new above number and override it, we don't need it anymore. I.e. 2*3=6
4. do the inital number multiplied by the first number and override it. I.e. 2*32=64
5. Add the result of step 3 to step 4. I.e. 64+6=70

E.g. 2 (in C#):
//72 of 7
int intitial = 7;
int multiplication = 72;
int A = 0;
int result = 0;

//step 1
//while(pow(2, A) <= multiplication){//2^0 = 1, 2^1 = 2, 2^2 = 4, 2^3 = 8, 2^4 = 16, 2^5 = 32, 2^6 = 64
//or better yet
A = 1;
while((A << 1) <= multiplication){//1 left shifted once: 2, 2 left shifted once: 4, e.c.t.
A++;//... A=6

}

//step 2
int B = multiplication-A;//B=8

//step 3
B = intitial*B;//same as B *= 7, hence you'll rarely see this in code
// 7*8=56

//step 4
A = intitial*A;//7*64=448
//which you'd have to override the '*' symbol to use this algorithm, so it'd start this again
//but as 7 of 64
//which would be:
//intitial = 64
//multiplication = 7
//step 1:
//A=2
//step 2:
//B = 7-2 = 5
//step 3:
//64*5:
//intitial = 5
//multiplication = 64
...
//which as you can see, at this point it's better to just leave it to the cpu's inbuilt algorithm unit - as that
//will be faster.

//step 5
result = A+B;//504

As someone who uses a password manager, i am quite disappointed with the sales pitch here.
I understand not wanting to go into details about how it works, but talking about "sending all your passwords to one company" naturally raises everyone's alarm bells.

A password manager uses a master password (that you have to input every time, not stored anywhere), to encrypt and decrypt the file all your other passwords are in
There are local managers (like keepass), which run only on one device and don't 'send your passwords' to anyone,
And then there's online managers (like lastpass), where the encrypted password file is stored online, but is still unusable unless you unlock it with your master password again

Given that your master password is strong enough (please, if you only need to remember one password, at least make it good people), then to get any of your passwords requires:
1) Getting your password file from a security breach / hacking into lastpass / stealing it from the inside (if possible?)
2) Trying different master passwords until one works
(the encryption is (hopefully) tuned so that it takes approx. 1 second to try one password on your computer, so brute force would be incredibly slow here)
3) Doing all of that before the breach is noticed and users change their passwords

And if you manage to do all that, congrats - you still only have a single user's passwords
Much more profitable to just hack a service you're interested in instead and get access to everyone's account there

A sure-fire way to open any fixed-code garage door is to simply modify the original transmitter. Make a very simple decade counter circuit and connect it to the original transmitter in place of the DIP switches. The decade counter will basically switch through every possible combination on the original remote so there will be zero problems with timing as you're using the original transmitter. It will open any door with the same receiver.

I made one when I was a kid with a CD4017BE counter that worked perfectly with an Elsema remote which was extremely common where I was. Then thankfully rolling code remotes took over. I haven't seen a fixed-code garage door remote here in Australia for a loooooooong time!

I have a quick comment on your "most common passwords" image at 0:50. That comment is scary, until you realize about its statistical significance. If everybody used ideal passwords (randomized extremely long strings), then two people sharing the same password would make that "the most common password". The relevance of the "most common passwords" isn't which ones they are (although if your password was in the image, please change it ASAP), but how common they actually are.

Don't think the mentioned method of hacking rolling codes would work. It assumes basically that there can be every time you hit the button the algorithm generates new random code on the remote control which can't be true. Here's why - if this was to be true - it would basically mean that if you ever pushed the button while out of range of receiver - you'd get synchronisation problem - receiver expects old code, but the remote control is already several codes ahead. Door is not opening. Since it doesn't happen - it should mean that the next code is generated only when receiver acknowledges the code. Which means that if the signal is jammed - the remote control should try same code over and over again instead of generating new code for every attempt. It would only work if receivever would accept any code  that can be generated with particular seed and not this particular next one in the sequence. I don't think it is the case as it has many other silly implications
